title: Investing Strategies During Cryptocurrency Market Crashes
keyQuestions: Why do crypto crashes happen so often, and what usually triggers them?
What early warning signals are most useful during fast drawdowns?
Which portfolio tactics reduce damage during high volatility?
How can DCA, rebalancing, and hedging fit into a single plan?
What should you do in the first 72 hours of a major selloff?
quickSteps: Pause before acting; separate liquidity stress from fundamental impairment.
Map exposures and liquidation risks (loans, perps, options, yield positions).
Execute with limits and staged orders; respect thin books and slippage.
Use pre-set DCA tranches and rebalancing bands instead of emotional buys/sells.
Rebuild optionality: restore cash buffers and tighten security after volatility spikes.

issueRouting.start: Start by stabilizing custody and access, then identify the single biggest failure mode (forced liquidation, counterparty risk, or bad execution) and neutralize it first.

branches.if: You have leverage or collateralized loans
then: Calculate liquidation thresholds and reduce exposure before volatility accelerates.
Add collateral or close positions to remove forced-selling risk.

branches.if: You are unleveraged but exposed to concentrated risk
then: Rebalance toward target weights using bands instead of impulse trades.
Upgrade quality: keep assets with durable fundamentals, exit broken theses.

branches.if: You want protection without liquidating core holdings
then: Use defined-budget hedges (partial short futures or option structures) sized to risk, not fear.
Set expiry/roll rules so protection doesn’t decay unnoticed.

riskNotes: Crashes can combine thin liquidity and forced liquidations; execution quality often matters as much as direction.
Counterparty failures and rehypothecation risk tend to surface during stress; diversify venues and prioritize self-custody.
Over-trading headlines and averaging down without re-underwriting fundamentals are common, avoidable mistakes.
